sub_title: Computational and Simulation Specialist, Reservoir Engineering Professional, Electrical Engineer with major in Systems & Control, Age-Group Swim Coach
summary: Professional with unique educational and employment background and ample international experience. Interested in engineering and R&D roles within the areas of my educational and professional fields of expertise: complex systems modeling & simulations, systems & control, AI/ML, petroleum/reservoir engineering, system identification and reduced-order modeling, numerical computations....

'employees': {'start': None, 'end': None}}, 'date': {'start': {'month': 9, 'day': None, 'year': 2001}, 'end': {'month': 2, 'day': None, 'year': 2009}}, 'profile_positions': [{'location': 'Delft University of Technology', 'date': {'start': {'month': 9, 'day': None, 'year': 2001}, 'end': {'month': 2, 'day': None, 'year': 2009}}, 'company': 'TU Delft', 'description': 'The main focus in the PhD project was to introduce techniques for model order reduction of high-dimensional reservoir simulation models using "system-theoretical" concepts of controllability, observability, minimal realizations and I/O transfer functions for single-phase models and data-driven techniques (proper orthogonal decomposition and similar) for two-phase reservoir simulations, respectively. At the very start of the PhD project the candidate also proposed the use of "subspace-identification" techniques for short-time prediction of (two-phase) hydrocarbon reservoirs. The PhD project was actually initially supposed to be a project on System Identification of Hydrocarbon Reservoirs using "Predictive Error Methods" (PEM) family (see the work of Lennart Ljung, for instance). To the candidate being an electrical engineer with a major in systems and control it was directly clear that such methods are (at that moment at least) most likely not the right way to go, so he proposed to change the focus, which fortunately was accepted.  
P.S. Due to personal circumstances the PhD project was interrupted during 2006-2007, in which period the PhD candidate was employed by Schlumberger in Abingdon UK.', 'title': 'Research Assistant / PhD student', 'employment_type': None}]}]
